prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple living together where the guy pays all the bills because his girlfriend works part-time. He's upset about her reaction when he made her pay for takeout, which was under $40.

First, I need to consider both sides. The guy has been handling all the expenses, which might be expected if there's a significant income difference. The girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she doesn't have much money. But the incident where he made her pay for the takeout led to her upset reaction. The guy feels she should contribute more, even if it's a small amount, for principal reasons.

Is he in the wrong? Well, maybe. If he's been paying everything, suddenly expecting her to pay for something small might be unfair, especially if she's already contributing in other ways. Also, her reaction could be due to feeling it's unfair she can't afford it. The guy might be overreacting to a minor issue, using this as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement. But he might also feel that she should start contributing, even a little, for fairness.

On the other hand, if he's been paying all along, maybe it's reasonable to want to adjust, but the way he approached it (making her pay without considering her ability) might be the problem. The question is whether the author is in the wrong. If he's using a single incident to demand more contribution, maybe he's being unfair. But if he's just adjusting expectations, maybe not. The key points are the existing arrangement and the approach taken. The answer could be A (he's wrong) because he's using a minor incident to change the financial setup, which might be unfair. Or B (not wrong) because he's seeking fairness. I think A is more likely, as the situation seems to be a minor issue blown out of proportion, and he's not considering her financial situation fully.
